review.title: Combining the analytical hierarchy process and the genetic algorithm to solve the timetable problem
review.abstract: The main problems of school course timetabling are time, curriculum, and classrooms. In addition there are other problems that vary from one institution to another. In addition, there are other problems that vary from institution to institution. This paper aims to solve the problem of meeting the teachers "preferred timetable in a way that takes into account the importance of the teacher for the supervisory institute, i.e. his score according to certain criteria. The Genetic Algorithm (GA) was presented as an elegant method of solving the timetable problem (TTP) in order to achieve conflict-free solutions. In this paper, we look at the analytical hierarchy process (AHP) in order to efficiently obtain a score for each teacher and thus produce a GA-based TTP solution that meets most teachers" preferences.

sections.heading: 2.1. Genetic algorithm
sections.text: A genetic algorithm is a kind of search algorithm. It seeks a space for an optimal solution to a problem. The main feature of the genetic algorithm is the way in which the search is carried out. The algorithm creates a "population" of possible solutions to the problem and lets it "develop" over several generations in order to find better and better solutions. Population is the collection of candidate solutions that we consider over the course of the algorithm. Over the generations of the algorithm, new members are "born" into the population, while others "die" from the population. A single solution in the population is called an individual. An individual's fitness function is a measure of how "good" the solution is that represents the individual. The better the solution, the higher the fitness - obviously this depends on the problem to be solved. The selection process corresponds to the survival of the individual in the natural world. Individuals are selected for "breeding" (or crossing) the solution that brings together the two individuals, each of whom they are placed in their own position - the two of the water.

sections.text: Different types of timetable problems appear in relation to educational institutions and depend on the elements that are planned, i.e. exams or regular courses. An excellent overview of the exam time techniques is given in Qu et al. [8]. The exam timetable is similar in most institutions and consists of scheduling the exams for a number of courses, over a limited period of time, while avoiding the duplication of exams for each student, as well as finding the largest dispersion over the exam period [9].However, the course timetable differs in relation to the institution, i.e. universities, schools. A course timetable problem essentially deals with the effective distribution of five types of units (or resources): spaces, courses, teachers, students and time (days and hours).In university timetables, the problem presents a large number of restrictions that need to be met.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This paper represents a new approach that addresses teacher preferences while simultaneously creating the timetable of a school curriculum. Our approach is to integrate a satisfaction function into the genetic algorithm. The parameters of the satisfaction function are teacher stress and a set of results calculated based on the analytical hierarchy process. The key point of the satisfaction function in the calculation of results is the paired comparison of a number of teacher criteria. Consequently, the new approach is a combination of AHP and GA, and it leads to a new methodology for solving the timetable problem that we call AHP / GA. In this paper, we present an informal description of our AHP / GA approach. The formal description and implementation of the process are perspective. In addition, we must review our contribution by applying the implemented AHP / GA to various case studies in Lebanese schools.
